description: From post-classical Latin prunella, from brunus + -ella, perhaps because of the plant's brown sepals.

entries.meaning: (botany) A member of the genus Prunella of herbaceous plants, the allheals. [from 16th c.]

description: From post-classical Latin prunella, alternation of brunella (“infectious epidemic”), from brunus + -ella.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, medicine) Any of various diseases characterised by inflammation of the mouth or throat. [17th–18th c.]

description: Probably a variant of prunello, with reference to the colour of the fabric. Compare French prunelle.

entries.meaning: (now rare, historical) A smooth worsted or silk fabric, generally black, formerly used for making shoes and clergymen's gowns. [from 17th c.]
examples: When Edna knocked at Mademoiselle Reisz's front room door and entered, she discovered that person standing beside the window, engaged in mending or patching an old prunella gaiter.
